Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2009 05:52AM REKoz wrote: I'd like to respond to this and if there are any great writers out there, I surely could use their help because a letter to my hospital administrator is most definitely in order. I had a bmx last November with immediate TE's and alloderm. What happened to me was that I developed a horrible post op infection. Some of this is still foggy because I was on Percocet and couldn't understand why I had so much pain. Long story short, when my entire chest was purple and black, I went back to my FORMER PS in agonizing pain despite the Percocet. This "professional" proceeded to empty my expanders of the 60cc saline he put in at surgery with absolutely NO pain protocol whatsoever. I thought I was going to die right there on his table!! He said he had nothing in his office to give me...not even something topical!!  When I thought I was going to pass out, he told me I should go to the emergency room if it continued!!! Then, he sends me on my way with a perscription of 2.5mg valium. They do not even make valium in 2.5 so that could not be filled!!!  He never changed my post op antibiotics! I feel like he took out the saline because to cover his a$$. I truly think the infection was due to overfill as I was FLAT to begin with and the incisions were just splitting!! By the grace of God, I saw the Oncologist for the first time 2 days later. He took one look at me and had me on IV Vancomyacin every day for 2 weeks!  He saved the expanders, and I switched Plastic Surgeons. Not only that but my first PS's bedside manner was the WORST ever. Like a macho man who could give a crap about us women! So for those who have just had surgery like mine, it is SO important to pay attention to both the looks of your chest and the amount of pain you are experiencing. If one is still experiencing ridiculous pain even with strong meds, an infection could be the culprit. I just get livid looking back but I am gentle with myself when I can't believe I wasn't in this guys face sooner. I couldn't expect myself to know anything about this procedure without having gone through it. I feel it's imperative that if I can help even one person avoid the hell I went through, I will have succeeded in this new mission of mine. So, any good writers want to help me out with my letter? I am still going through recon with another PS (excellent) in the same practice. Can't be sent till I am all done a few months from now! I'd really appreciate some help. Not one other women should have to deal with this man!!

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2011 03:48PM REKoz wrote: Hi Ladies- I just had my 6 month visit with my Onc. and thought I'd share what he told me when I asked about Zometa. Though newly menopausal when diagnosed, I am taking Tamoxifen rather than the AL's tried but not tolerated AT ALL. He said that the Tamox. actually has a bone protecting effect. If my next bone density test shows a decline, we would discuss it then. But he feels that as long as my bones are good now and I am on Tamox., I should be fine. It would be a different story if I were on AL's. This was news to me. Good news actually. Thought I'd pass that on to those of you on Tamox. who like me were unaware of this. Nice to put something about it in the plus column! My best to all, Ellen

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2009 02:07PM REKoz wrote: Donna- We have to get it together about which thread we are going to be "chatting" on! I wrote to you on the other a few hours ago. Anyway, absolutely ZERO need to thank me. We are all here for each other and thank God for that. I see it as a gift to have the supportive nature of my fellow travelers in a way I have with my close real life friendships. Even though there is no face to face (we don't even know what some of us look like-I must work on posting a pix for that more personal feel). Though in this case my friends, although incredibly supportive can't get me through some of this the same way as those traveling the exact same road. To answer your question, I don't know if you remember but I had a horrible post op infection and almost lost the expanders after my Nov. 10th surgery. As a result, I had to wait until that was resolved before I started chemo. It was down to the last minute I'm telling you! The expanders were going to have to go if the scar revision was not successful before mid Jan. That was the chemo wait deadline and I started on the 16th! Now, I will not get filled AT ALL (they took out what was put in during surgery during infection) until after chemo. I have come to terms with that but only because I was thankful that I didn't have to get them out! It's all about PERSPECTIVE..life in general and this bc for sure! I swore I would NOT under any circumstances do chemo when first diagnosed and actually had some of my friends believing they would have to sit me down and beg when I found out I had to have it! What really tips me in the chemo favor is the fact that they found this (and yours too) early and I really feel that once I'm done, my chances are real good to live life cancer free. I still don't know if I would do it if my prognosis was poor. I've learned to never say never but I do not see myself as one with the special constitution it takes to get through that. Now, my friends, family see me as strong but I see it as doing what I have to do. I am not going to sugar coat it for you, I HATE chemo. Even though my se's are not as bad as many of my "sisters" here, I just hate feeling like crap(no pun intended) constantly. As I wrote on the other board, I am now on my 1 week vacation after Fridays tx. First of 4. So, now I am feeling the effects of that and if it's like last week, it's downhill from today and peaks on Tuesday. Am soo looking forward to feeling good for an entire week! Thoughts of having to be drugged and dragged to the next cycle enter my mind frequently! But perservere I will and get through this because there IS light at the end of the tunnel. Plus, I have to be in good shape for my oldest (of  2) daughter's July 25th wedding!  Just pray for constantly for strength, use your life resources and these boards and we'll get thru this! The beauty of this support here is that my writing this to you reinforces what I know to be true regardless of how I sometimes feel otherwise. We make each other stronger in the most incredible ways! Look forward to hearing back from you and I always look forward to read about other's journeys to strengthen my own. Hugs, Ellen

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2012 11:40AM REKoz wrote: I had Abraxane and Carbo. as my chemo treatment 3 years ago.  Herceptin was also in that mix since I was HER2+.  It looks as though my schedule was the same as well.  Rather than once every 3 weeks, I went weekly x 3 and had a week off before beginning the next round.  12 weeks on that protocol is equivalent to 4 treatments for someone going every 3 weeks. When I was going through treatment, I was unable to connect with any other early stager on this site on this protocol.  It is my understanding that due to it's very high cost, most insurance co.'s will only approve Abraxane for our Stage 4 sisters. Many of whom have previously been treated with carbo among other chemos.  Needless to say then, there is a valid reason for the lack of responses to your post. There are so few of us around to have been treated with this protocol as our first line chemo! I'd be happy to answer any questions or share my experience if it will be helpful to you. I remember well the mental lift I got when passing the halfway point in chemo.  I might not have been feeling too swift physically, but my head was buzzing with excitement each time I remembered that more treatment was behind me than in front of me! Best, Ellen

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2009 11:42AM REKoz wrote: I've not visited the Mets board until now. I've been following this issue as a Social Worker, always interested in resolving issues. Certainly, I do not pretend that I can resolve this but I would like to add my input. First and most importantly, I would never even presume to identify with the feelings of anyone dealing with mets. How could I? I've not walked in your shoes and cannot even begin to fathom how I would feel. Like anything else in life, not one person can claim to know how they would feel, react etc. unless they've "been there." IMO, anyone who thinks otherwise has much growing up to do. It's just a fact of life in my mind. Unfortunately, our culture has become so incredibly judgemental that often times, people confuse judgement with knowledge. A very sad commentary on where we've come. But that's for another discussion. I just want to say from my experience as a "newbie", I joined this site with absolutely no clue on where to start. Someone mentioned that there are many who do not understand the "unwritten rules" when posting here. I was one of them until I followed this thread. I still post by scrolling through active topics and obviously as an early stager, have not hit on an issue that applies to me on the mets board. I guess my point is that it may make sense to somehow inform newbies of those "unwritten rules." Aside from the emotional need to seek answers when first diagnosed, many women have not even participated in internet discussion groups before. Those that have are certainly more savy about where and what to post. So, whether it be a seperate forum for just metsters, or some sort of notice to those just joining the community, clarity might prevent those clueless (but not necessarily hurtful) individuals from inadvertantly being insensative to the needs of those courageous Stage iv women. God Bless you All. Ellen

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2011 12:37PM REKoz wrote: Add me to the list of those who had too much going on inside a very small left breast where a lumpectomy was not an option. I chose to have a bilateral but not without agonizing over it. The first sign FOR ME was seeing the image of having just one breast removed. The fear and horror I felt was completely unexpected. Perhaps it was reality setting in but other then discovering I had to have chemo, that was the only other day I broke down uncontrollably. For some reason, the visual of missing one of a pair freaked me out. Since I knew I would have recon on the cancer breast, I learned that I would likely have surgery on the other (anyway) for a better match. And of course, I'd still have the anxiety of annual mammo's (which is how they found the left bc). Finally, my father in law who is an MD (admittedly of the older school) expressed his strong belief that if it were his wife or daughters, he'd encourage doing both. His feeling is that if a woman is past child bearing age and cancer is found in any female related part, the optimal resolution is remove in it's entirety. Of course, there are hundreds of survivors who did not go this route so I am not claiming that he is right and others wrong. Just saying that his opinion factored into my decision as well. And finally, I am a believer of people coming into your life for a reason. I got to talking to a wonderful woman fighting stage 4 for the past 10 years. When I told her I was leaning toward a bmx, she said that she wished she had done that when first diagnosed stage 2. We both agreed that her outcome could very well have been the same but she lives with the "what if." That sealed the deal for me. I don't need to live with anymore regrets than I already have! The recon (exanders-implant) was long and not complication free, I have yet to decide if I will go for nips. In clothes, I look great and even without, I do have to matching breasts albeit without feeling. A sexual complication I had not even considered but have found to be a HUGE loss in terms of responsiveness. I know that I wouldn't have done this any other way, I didn't know that I'd be living with a "what if" anyway. What if I kept the healthy breast that responded more than I ever imagined before this all happened?  To say this all blows is an understatement! My best wishes for peace with whatever you decide.

Fatigue a bigger issue though...2 days in a row of 3-4 hour naps! Never was a napper and hate sleeping the afternoon away. Oh well, I'll take this over stomach havoc anytime. Ellen

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2009 05:23PM REKoz wrote: ddlatt- I posted here early on as I started chemo in Jan. Sorta drifted over to the TCH thread as that is the chemo closest to mine. But instead of Taxotere, I have been on Abraxane from the start (c-carboplatin, H-herceptin). It is $$$ and most insurance will only pay for late stagers. My Onc. was able to get it for me due to my bilateral carpal and the fact that it is less likely to cause neuropathy. That holds true due to it's composition and the fact that no pre meds (which also cause nueropathy) are required. Keep in mind that I go weekly x 3 instead of every three. But my hands have held out wonderfully! I'll get the tingling in both hands and feet but not often and it is very manageable. I have one more cycle to go and thus far have had no nail problems either. I hope to say the same at the end of treatment! If you can get it, you may find it much more tolerable. I do have Emend after starting of with Zofran as the nausea got worse. But that could be more from the carbo. Best of luck to you. Ellen

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2011 12:09AM REKoz wrote: Hi Meg- Can I assume that you did Herceptin as you didn't mention it and you are HER2+? Our stats are similar other then the fact that I was ER+. Very small of chest, I had no option but to have a mastectomy and decided to do a bilateral. My Onc. told me I had a 95% chance of now being surgically "cured" followed by 5 years of an anti hormonal (which you won't need).  I totally understand why you would be fearful. Especially because all that positive "self talk" that it wasn't cancer didn't help. Do you still have any meds for anti-anxiety? If anything is going to put your anxiety into overdrive, it's this! I know that there is always the possibility that I may not fall into the 95% of those who remain cancer free. But there's a far better chance that I won't. That helps me deal with the fear of return. What also helps me is the thought that I got through this when in the beginning, I truly did not think I would mentally survive (especially chemo!)  Though I am not dealing with anything that provokes fear that it's back, I have learned that I can't change a THING that is unknowlingly going on in my body. There are so many "what ifs" that could drive you crazy. I need every ounce of energy I can get and am determined not to let my fears gobble it up until I know exactly what I am dealing with. I think it's wise to get into the Dr. when you can but until then, you don't know what it is. The odds are on your side that it is not cancer. Try to remember that until you see the Dr. Hugs to you and please update. Ellen

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2010 01:20PM REKoz wrote: You're not a moron! How many of us knew anything about wigs before chemo? It's just another of the many issues we suddenly have to become knowledgeable about. I am fortunate enough to have excellent insurance so I went to a shop that specializes in all things cancer. I actually got fitted for my wig and YES, there is a nylon( I think there are other materials as well) cap to wear under and keep them in place. I also had a synthetic wig and washed it as you would your own hair. Purchased synthetic wig shampoo and conditioner from TLC, which I'm pretty sure you can get to through the American Cancer Assoc. site. I found that to be cheaper then most others. You can also get the cap to wear underneath there. Though my wig was great (I'd love the same "cut" now with my hair back), I totally hear you on the "oddness" of wearing it. No matter how good it looks, it's very difficult to "forget" that it's not a natural part of you. Just another reminder of what you're going through. The last time I wore mine was at my daughter's wedding- almost 3 months after finishing chemo but still on Herceptin. After being completely bald, the little hair I had growing in was good enough for me to ditch the wig! Best wishes to you for a smooth and successful recovery. Believe it or not, you will look back and think it went fast. I can hardly relate to that bald person I see in pictures now. Thank God!

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2011 09:34AM REKoz wrote: I'm thinking that the title of this thread is a little misleading. Seems that the real issue is your feeling that because you are early stage, people don't understand what you've been through and/or the mental trauma caused by any cancer diagnosis. I can't imagine why one would feel guilty because their cancer isn't worse!  Spend more time on these boards learning what life is like for our stage 4 sisters, check out the ever growing list of angels who lost the fight leaving behind hundreds of motherless children. Realize that the majority of us early stagers will never have to put up a fight again while many are fighting everyday against the demon that has overtaken their lives and will likely win the battle for the body one day. I do know the feeling (especially toward the end of treatment) that those around you assume you will easily move on once treatment is over. It was caught early, you were treated and your odds are good that it won't return. Many of us have found the most challenging time mentally is when treatment is over and we are left to our own devices to navigate a "new normal." We will never be the same as we were- no one ever is after experiencing trauma. And though you may feel like a fish out of water for a time, it does get better. Believe me, I am anything but Polly Positive and I can still let what's happened get me down sometimes. But I am always grateful that I have been given the opportunity TO move on with great odds that I left friggin cancer behind. Involuntarily entered into the lottery that is breast cancer, I feel like I have a winning ticket. I just wish we all did. My heart couldn't feel more for those not as fortunate.

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2009 11:47AM REKoz wrote: Oh am I EVER happy to see this post! I had a bilateral mastectomy on Nov. 10th. It was the Plastic Surgeon who was MERCILESS on me about my smoking. He was the most pompous, unfeeling moralistically superior a-hole mentioned it within every sentence he uttered. He set me up for all sorts of problems and guess what? I had them..a NASTY infection that set me back a month and caused me to have a scar revision which thankfully looks great now...NOW that I have a new PS! No question, smoking effects healing. In my case though, I am convinced orig. PS overfilled my expanders initially which pulled the incision apart. When the Home care nurse said get your butt to the PS, you are developing an infection, all this guy did was take all the fluid out that HE put in. The pain was beyond belief and I almost had to go to the emergency room. No numbing, no nothing (said he had nothing??)..just stuck needles into infected mastectomy! Sends me home with no change in the basic ""leave the hospital antibiotics. No question this guy was trying to save his butt by getting all the fluid out and told me to come back in a week! Thank God for my oncologist! When I saw him two days (and out of my mind pain later), he immediately put me on 12 days IV Vancomyocin. Luckily, I had a port put in at surgery because I knew I'd be on Herceptin for a year!  Infection cleared which so fortunately saved me from expander removal. However, we will not be even discussing beginning to fill for at least a month and maybe not till I'm done with chemo should I run into any problems there. My new PS also highly suggests (without making me feel like a peice of dirt) no smoking and I have cut down considerably. Neither of them would have done a DIEP as a smoker even if I had been a candidate. I have read alot of literature concurrent with that opinion. Anyway, I start chemo tomorrow...Abraxane, Carboplatin and Herception 3 weeks on, one off for 12 cycles. I have been told that without having to take steriods, this may be easier on me. Hope so because I HAVE to return to work on Tues! I am thinking this protocol will significantly lessen my enjoyment of smoking and contribute greatly to my strong desire to stop all together. I'm with you ladies as far as feeling so stupid adding carcinogins into an already cancerous body. But also identify with the feeling that it's been darn near impossible under this stress. My mantra is that chemo will SUCK, but it will be my friend. Metal tastes do not bode well for any mouth input, let alone cigs! Love these boards and hope to get to "know" some of you better! Best of luck to all! Ellen

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2009 06:53AM REKoz wrote: Just adding what my Onc. told me my daughters (27, 24) should do which absolutely confirms JeansBeans experience. My mother (age 77, 3 yrs ago) and now me at age 53 is most certainly within the criteria for risk. Mom did not have to BRCA test but I did and it was negative. I'm convinced further research will uncover more genetic variables as no one can talk me out of thinking my girls ARE at high risk. Anyway, my Onc.'s opinion is that the girls each get a baseline MRI at age 30. Earlier would be OK with me but the point is, it's the MRI and not an initial mammo that will be their starting point. In regard to the hormonals in particularly diary and meat, organic is all I will buy now and have stressed same to my daughters. Highly hormonal positive makes me think that my past history of LOVING milk and drinking it by the gallons as it was a "good" thing was in fact a great aide in developing this cancer. Same could be said for the Irish meat and potato upbringing I had and passed on to them! It's hard for them to fully grasp how to undo everything they learned. Just as it was for me. I just pray that they never have to find out the hard way like I did!  And I try not to dwell on my anger that they put out and APPROVE so many carcinogenic products to begin with. There has to be a multitude of people that think we are somehow "protected" as I thought my whole naive life! God Bless us all! Ellen

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2009 10:23AM REKoz wrote: Hi- I have posted here once or twice before starting chemo yesterday. I haven't seen anyone on this board with the same protocol as me. Has me curious. Instead of taxotere, I am getting Carboplatin and Abraxane which I am told is IAbraxane) easier on the system and does not require steriods. I have carpal tunnel and hand issues and this drug is also supposed to be better at avoiding neuropathy. The Oncol. (LOVE him) had to fight insurance because usually this is given to higher stage cancer or reoccurrent bc. I am also HER2 pos which adds Herceptin to the regiman. I am on a 3 weeks on, one week off for a total of 12 treatments. Also told on this protocol, se's may be less due to smaller doses. I got anti nausea shot in the port prior to treatment and have Zofran to take at home. After chemo, I just felt really tired but the biggest issue seems to be headaches.  I have been fortunate enough to not have problems with headaches in my life. I have none of the other meds I have seen here. Is there anyone familiar with this type of protocol? I am returning to work on Tues. since my bilateral with expanders on Nov. 10th. Nasty post op infection, 12 days IV Vancomyacin and finally scar revision which now looks as if it should have after surgery. Hoping I'm not pushing it by returning to work (adm. asst-desk job) but have run out of sick time and $$! I have to do what I have to do. My cancer was discovered exactly one year to the month of my last period ( I'm 53) so I have had some experiences with those blasted hot flashes which only get worse! One thing I thought I'd mention-particularly to you younger girls going into forced menopause- is that my Oncologist has me on the anti depressent Effexor. I actually went on Wellbutrin at the advice of my Gyno when diagnosed and did feel that helped. However, after surgery I could NOT sleep to begin with and everytime I nodded, I'd be awoken by a hot flash. The Oncol. said that Effexor has been proven to help about 60% of woman with hot flashes. It's only been a month and I do still have them but less frequently. AND, I get a full night of sleep! Thought maybe it might be worth talking to your MD's about. Ellen

Her Dad and I were married 25 years and he has since remarried and lives in China! We are the "Bruce and Demi" of common folk though and he has been wonderful in both emotional and financial support. As far as the recur anxiety (Dianetoo), I think it might be due to where I am. As a weekly person, I just start to feel better and then it's back to BLECH. Today is #3 and then a week off so I am trying to focus on that wonderful fact instead of the fact of physically going downhill after today. As weird as it seems, for me, the biggest issue with recur is more chemo. Of course the cancer itself is not a happy thought but it's the thought of continual chemo that just does not seem doable to me. I am far from an anxious person and it does not occupy my mind, I just HATE HATE HATE feeling so gross. Believe it or not, I've come to terms with everything but this friggin chemo! Well, it's off to the shower b/4 I leave for that friggin chemo!  At least it's a great motivator to get my work done as I bring my laptop and it makes the time go super fast. Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2009 09:55AM REKoz wrote: Morning Jewels- Renrel-I went to the AMC Look Good Feel Better program the other night. They showed a great trick for head covering with a mans undershirt. I am going to look in the dollar stores for t shirts in different colors. They cut off right under the arms of an x-tra large size so all thats left is the torso. Open the shirt in a circle and twist the entire thing. Then take one section to your forhead and open it over your head all the while holding the rest of the twisted part behind you. Then you fold one rear twist over the other and bring around to front (like you would do with a towel for when you had hair and washed it!) It looks really good and being cotton is very comfy. I hope you can visualize that. It might work for you. My chemo is weekly x 3 with one week off in between.  On Friday (the 13th so friggin appropriate), I will begin the second round of 3 (of 4 total). I DREAD it as I have been feeling almost like my old self for a week now. I really, really don't want to go back...whaa whaa. This does indeed stink more than any stink I will be making next week! Enjoy the day. It's beautiful here in the East. A huge tease for spring. Ellen

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2009 07:05PM REKoz wrote: Hi Janet- Although this is my first (and God willing last) go at chemo, I am on Abraxane as well as Carboplatin and Herceptin.My Onco. was able to get this approved even though I am early stage for a bunch of reasons. Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2009 10:34AM REKoz wrote: Hi Everyone- My name is Ellen and I am just thrilled to be part of a "group" having to deal with the experience of this very difficult journey. I had a bilateral mastectomy with expanders on Nov. 10th which was unfortunately followed by a very NASTY infection.Since I am HER2+, I had a port put in at the same time as surgery with a year of Herceptin treatment looming. Very fortunate there as I had  almost 2 weeks on IV Vancomyacin. Infection cleared and I just had the eschar removal and scar revision done last week. Unfortunately (again) a few stiches popped on the lymph surgery side which was just packed and resewn with both disolvable and permanent stitches. Left arm in a sling as a do not use "reminder." It has to stay bandaged until I see PS on Monday but the wound was clean and there does not seem to be any signs of infection. I've been on some sort of antibiotics since surgery so I had developed thrush,(UGH) which has since cleared on antifungals. It sure makes me very afraid of mouth sores when chemo starts though! I'm so glad I've read about the throat coat and absolutely plan on ordering that! Anyway, if the PS clears me, I will be starting chemo (carboplatin, taxotere or abraxane which he-my GREAT oncologist- would prefer but may not be covered as an early stage patient) along with Herceptin and anti estrogen in pill form (think Femara, not 100% sure). Originally, I was to be on a 3 week cycle for 12 weeks but he has changed it to weekly with my penchant for infections. The Herceptin will continue for one year on 3 weeks after chemo. Since that change, he took Neulasta off my perscription list and only kept Zofran for nausea.From reading this, I'm thinking I'm glad Neulasta is not in the picture! I'm so looking forward to "getting to know" my fellow travellers, comparing notes, advice and most importantly...support. My work situation gives me a little more time of getting by but I REALLY want to go back asap. I believe that will be discussed with my Oncologist once treatment starts and how it effects me is known, My oldest daughter (27...I'm 53, another daughter almost 24), is getting married on July 25th and the sooner this treatment starts, the sooner I can focus on what will be one of the most special days of my life! Not to mention hers and the fact that she can get the attention she so deserves. Of course, she just cares about me getting better but as all you Mom's know, I want to be able to give her all I've got! Thanks Lisa for starting this thread (I am soo jealous that you live where you can get instant therapy from warm sunshine along an ocean beach!...too cold on out LI beaches now!) and I for sure plan on being an active member of the "Jewels!"

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2009 09:51AM REKoz wrote: All I can say is just DITTO all of the above posts re: this emotional roller coaster, the public perception of us going through bc and our own private thoughts. The feelings of needing things from people whether in words or deeds at some times but not at others. How those "not now" times can cause a bigger funk through no fault of the giver. How we could NEVER explain to that person why we feel what we do at particular times. And the guilt we feel when we feel offended when one causes an emotional nosedive when their intentions were so good. And the guilt we feel when we are just flat down for the count while the others are shouldering our former "duties." As I've said to those close to me, having this bc is just ALWAYS present. I explain that it's not as if I constantly go into a pity pot and let it depress me. Actually, I rarely do. It's just that this experience is so very POWERFUL on every emotional level and we so often are ruled by the power of it all in ways that we ourselves don't expect. I cannot WAIT to look back and say: "What a long strange trip it's been!" Blessings, Ellen

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2009 09:09AM REKoz wrote: Hello Jewels I'm back after round one of three, cycle 2 (of 4.) I am on a different protocol then just about anyone else I have seen here. I'm on Abraxane which is the same as taxotere but does not require steroids because it has a "natural absorption quality" unlike taxotere. From all that I've read, that's a good thing because the steroids seem to cause more problems then the chemo. Abraxane is only approved for mets but due to the fact that I have pre existing nerve issues in my hands and I have to work, the dear Oncologist was able to persuade the insurance co. I am also on Carboplatin and Herceptin. The first cycle had me feeling the worst on Mon. and Tues so we shall see what happens this time. Surely I have learned that you can't predict anything as far as treatment goes. I have a Caringbridge website and on Tues. I had written that my hair was intact. That drastically changed on Thurs. and by yesterday I decided that I did not want to be dealing with the emotional and physical mess that was rapidly developing from my head. So, I bit the bullet and went for the shave after chemo. The hairdresser used the longest setting so it is not truly bald per se. About an inch of spikey and OH MY, wayyyy too much gray was hiding under all that thickness! I have 4 brothers (and a sister) and I mentioned that I now look just like my bro's, in all aspects except for from the waist down!  I see the PS on Monday and am anxious to see if he will reconsider his declaration of no fills of the expanders until after chemo. That was his thinking last month after that nasty infection and scar revision. Though now the scars look nice and healed. I would not risk it all just for a few fills but sure would be nice if he was comfortable doing so! Have a wonderful long weekend ladies. I am looking forward to my daughter coming during the week. Lucky her, as a School Social Worker, she gets all the vacations, including the entire summer! We are going to pick out wedding invites and start planning the shower. It surely is a great thing to have in my life now. I just wish I could give it the focus and prominence it would ordinarily get from me. Later Raiders..or more appropriately, fellow warriors! Ellen

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2012 02:09PM REKoz wrote: Unless I am reading this wrong two thoughts immediately come to mind. The first is that this post does not belong in this forum but rather "Not diagnosed but concerned About Metastasis." I can surely understand how this mistake may occur and because it happened so often, the forum mentioned above was created. I'm not on here often anymore. When I am, I scroll "Active Topics" and thus arrived here. It's even a little uncomfortable posting a response so I hope this gets moved. Thought #2: This thread is a tad difficult to follow and please correct me if I'm wrong Sallyyy. I'm assuming you had a PET sometime after Nov. diagnosis of Stage 1 HER2+, finished your chemo and are now continuing with Herceptin only for the rest of the year? That PET showed lung nodules too small to biopsy and you're concerned that they may be cancer as well? If that's correct, then I can share my experience because my stats are identical. One person responded accurately that under these circumstances, you're Onc. will want to rescan to see if they grow or change in any way. Also spot on was the comment that this is very common (though unknown) among the population in general. We know because we have PET scans and it can be due to all sorts of benign reasons (past pneumonia, infection, allergies etc. etc.) I am scanned annually now to monitor several lung nodules and they have remained unchanged since my first scan in late '08. If you look around the site, you will find many like us with benign nodules. This is not to say that it couldn't possibly be worse, but the odds are in your favor- particularly since your nodes were clear.    My Oncologist never recommended staying on chemo longer! I'm surprised at that suggestion since I've never seen (on here or read about) an early stager with unspecified lung nodules to continue on prolonged chemo!  I'm thinking if it wasn't me misinterpreting, then those who suggested that course have. They may have assumed you are Stage 4 because that is where you posted.  That's an altogether different situation....

Although I can't claim to have not lost it before surgery, I have found this a process similar to grief (and no wonder, grief is certainly warranted!) Though I have been much better since chemo ended, I find my sadness comes in waves and sometimes out of nowhere. From surgery through chemo, those waves would lead to crying spells. Now when they come, I just get depressed. I don't dwell and try to look at the reality that it could be much worse. But losing a chunk of the carefree person I was does get me down. If I've learned anything at all, it's definitely the fact that I've given myself permission to accept whatever I feel at any given time. Good luck to you!

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2009 08:44AM REKoz wrote: Dear Lifeisbeautiful- At this time last year, I was exactly where you are. Not procedure wise (I had a double mx) but most certainly mentally. It's a place we ALL have been and you would be hard pressed to find someone who didn't say this is the worst stage in the whole process. You are in shock and just overwrought with fear. While I won't go so far as to say it get's easy from here, I will say that you WILL come back to reality and do what you must with some sense of acceptance.Knowledge is power!! I did not find this site until after my surgery but before chemo. It helped me beyond words to learn about chemo (and SO much more), get support,reassurance and yes, love from my fellow travelers.  So in that respect, you are fortunate to be here from the get go. I know for me, there has never been a more frightening or "feeling alone" experience in my life then when first diagnosed. By being here, you WILL discover that you are indeed not alone and the support you will receive will be huge in helping you deal with fear. I'm sorry I cannot address your specific questions, but more info is needed to answer them. There's a stage 2 and a grade 2 (which on a 1-3 scale defines particular characteristics of the cancer and it's aggressiveness). Do you have a biopsy report to refer to? Anyway, I just wanted to chime in and lend my support in this oh so very traumatic time. You WILL get through this, just keep putting one foot in front of the other. And if you are a person of faith, you will find that extremely helpful as well. Blessings to you.

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2011 11:16AM REKoz wrote: Hi Jane- Sorry you haven't received any replies yet. I believe that's because Abraxane is not commonly given to us early stagers thereby making it difficult to find someone in a similar position to share their experience. At least that's what I found while I was going through my chemo cocktail of Abraxane and Carboplatin (along with Herceptin for HER2+). My feeling is that we are in the very fortunate minority. It is very expensive and not easy to get through insurance approval at stage 1.  My scientific knowledge is FAR from stellar but because of it's chemical make up, Abraxane does not require having to take Neulasta or Decatron.  From all that I have gleaned from our sisters here, they can be as difficult as the chemo itself. If you read up on it, you'll see it has something to do with not having the chemical compounds that add to the SE's of the other taxanes. This is why it is considered a more "gentle" chemo according to my Onc. He pushed it through for me due to pre existing neuropathy issues as well as my need to return to work during chemo. Now for your $10,000 question...how did I make out on it? Not bad in comparison to the other Taxane ladies I believe. Of course everyone is different and chemo in any form is not- as they say- "a walk in the park." My hair did begin to fall out in clumps. I shaved it before it got to be too much and the scalp relief was instantaneous! The Zofran which worked early on for nausea was not good enough as I progressed. I HIGHLY recommend asking for Emend asap if you find this the case for you. I suffered needlessly because I waited. And there was fatigue- also more prominent as I went along. While not SE free by any means, reading the SE experiences of ladies on other chemo protocols did always give me reason to believe it could be worse. I had to delay my last chemo due to low blood counts. They came back to acceptable range the following week which put me 2 weeks out from my next surgery. In order to insure my counts were good for that, my Onc. dropped the Carbo from my last chemo. Interestingly enough, my SE's were far more tolerable. I'm thinking that means that the Abraxane was the more gentle drug. I do hope this dissertation was of some help to you. Wishing you all the best as you go through treatment!!  I pop on this board often so please don't hesitate to reach out if you need to. Ellen

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2012 07:35AM REKoz wrote: Like marywh, I was 3 weeks on and one off. It was set up that way with the idea that it would produce the minimum amount of side effects and thus enable me to keep working. As is usually the case, the further along I got, the harder it was to do that. Moving from Zofran to Emend was a Godsend as far as the nausea. It made all the difference not feeling so sick-anything else was tolerable. I did end up taking more time off from work because I did become a vacant zombie like slug... Kelpie- What is your drug combo and protocol?  My experience is that you are entirely correct regarding what other chemo you have with Abraxane.  When I went in for my last chemo, my counts were not good and I was scheduled for a recon procedure a few weeks later. To enable that to happen, my Onc. left out the carbo for my last treatment. I felt infinitely better without it and am convinced that was the drug that gave me the most problems.
